Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E: Black Holes in Dense Star Clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many stars form in large clusters containing anywhere from thousands to many millions of objects. Stars in these clusters are born with a broad range of masses. Furthermore, the most massive stars evolve quickly, ending their lives in just a few million years and leaving behind black holes as remnants. The star clusters themselves, however, can continue to live for many billions of years, and indeed the globular clusters seen in many galaxies are thought to contain some of the oldest stars in the Universe. Therefore, many of the star clusters we see today should contain large numbers of black holes formed a long time ago. This research will use state-of-the-art supercomputer simulations to study the formation and evolution of these black holes in a variety of star cluster environments. It will also leverage innovative hybrid computational techniques, including General-Purpose computing on Graphics Processing Units (GPGPU).

The study of black hole formation and evolution is important in many areas of physics and astronomy, including galaxy formation and cosmology, the study of quasars and other active galactic nuclei, general relativity and gravitational wave astronomy. The stellar dynamics supercomputer codes to be developed for this project are general tools, which will be useful for studying many other problems involving dense star clusters with or without massive black holes. The planned research activities will involve the training of undergraduate students at Northwestern University, and will likely include students from under-represented minorities. Graduate students will also receive training and mentoring. Outreach activities are also planned that will take advantage of Dearborn Observatory on the Northwestern campus in Evanston, as well as the resources of the nearby Adler Planetarium and Astronomy Museum in Chicago.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many stars form in large clusters containing anywhere from thousands to many millions of objects. Stars in these clusters are born with a broad mass spectrum and the most massive ones evolve quickly, ending their lives in just a few million years and leaving behind black holes as remnants. The star clusters themselves, however, can continue to live for many billions of years, and indeed the globular clusters seen in many galaxies are thought to contain some of the oldest stars in the Universe. Therefore, many of the star clusters we see today should contain large numbers of black holes formed a long time ago. Our work led to the development of new, state-of-the-art supercomputer simulations to study the formation and evolution of these black holes in a variety of star cluster environments.

Our work demonstrated that dynamical interactions between stars can lead to the formation of large numbers of important sources in star clusters. Through gravitational encounters, black holes can rapidly concentrate in the dense inner cores of clusters, where the rates of dynamical interactions are very high. Such interactions then lead to the formation of many sources of great interest to physicists and astronomers: for example, bright X-ray binaries studied by space-based observatories such as NASA’s Chandra satellite, and strong gravitational-wave sources that have recently become detectable by instruments such as the NSF-funded LIGO. Because they lose energy by emitting gravitational radiation, black holes in tight binaries can ultimately merge. Through successive mergers, perhaps helped by accretion of gas, a much more massive black hole can sometimes be formed. Some direct evidence for such massive black holes, with masses up to thousands of solar masses, has come from recent detections of ultraluminous X-ray sources associated with star clusters.

The study of black hole formation and evolution is important in many areas of physics and astronomy, including galaxy formation and cosmology, the study of quasars and other active galactic nuclei, general relativity and gravitational wave astronomy. The stellar dynamics supercomputer codes that were developed for this project are general tools, which will be useful for studying many other problems involving dense star clusters with or without massive black holes. Some of the novel algorithms and numerical techniques, especially for parallelizing the computations, are of wide applicability to problems involving classical systems of interacting particles, even in areas well outside astronomy such as plasma physics and nuclear engineering. 

Our research activities contributed significantly to the training of graduate and undergraduate students at Northwestern University, including students from under-represented minorities.
